trustZone.name: Application Trust Zone (High Trust)
trustZone.desc:
Contains core business logic and security controls.
Manages transaction processing and validation.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-784
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-784: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie, but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies, within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Attackers can bypass protection mechanisms such as authorization and authentication by modifying the cookie to contain an expected value.

weakness.name: CWE-786
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-786: Access of Memory Location Before Start of Buffer The product reads or writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer. This typically occurs when a pointer or its index is decremented to a position before the buffer, when pointer arithmetic results in a position before the beginning of the valid memory location, or when a negative index is used.

countermeasure.name: Continuously monitor chatbot interactions and update training data to eliminate bias
countermeasure.desc:
Implement continuous monitoring of chatbot interactions to identify and address any potential biases in the responses. Regularly review the chatbot's training data and update it with diverse, representative data to ensure fair and unbiased interactions with users. This practice helps prevent the chatbot from reinforcing stereotypes or providing discriminatory responses, ensuring an inclusive and equitable user experience.

References:

  • OWASP Best Practices for Preventing AI Bias

standard.ref: Information security awareness, education and training
PR.AT-1: All users are informed and trained
PR.AT-2: Privileged users understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-3: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-4: Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.AT-5: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities

countermeasure.name: Ensure data is transmitted over secure protocols like HTTPS
countermeasure.desc:
Implement HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure) for all data transmissions to ensure encryption during transit, preventing unauthorized interception and tampering of sensitive data. By enforcing the use of HTTPS, you protect chatbot communications and user data from man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks and other forms of eavesdropping. This ensures data integrity and confidentiality between users and the chatbot system.

References:

  • Secure Communication Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement end-to-end encryption for chatbot conversations
countermeasure.desc:
Implement end-to-end encryption (E2EE) for all chatbot conversations to ensure that user data is encrypted during transit and can only be decrypted by the intended recipient. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive information by protecting messages from being intercepted or read by attackers or third parties during transmission. Both the chatbot and the users device should perform encryption and decryption operations, ensuring complete confidentiality throughout the communication process.

References:

  • OWASP End-to-End Encryption Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Perform regular security evaluations of integrated services
countermeasure.desc:
Conduct regular security evaluations of all third-party services and APIs integrated with the chatbot. This includes assessing security configurations, checking for vulnerabilities, ensuring compliance with security best practices, and verifying that all integrated services are updated to the latest secure versions. Regular evaluations help identify and mitigate potential risks that could be exploited, ensuring that the overall security posture of the chatbot remains strong and resilient to attacks.

References:

  • OWASP API Security Top 10

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Require multi-factor authentication for accessing the chatbot
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) or other strong authentication methods before granting users access to the chatbot. This additional layer of security helps ensure that only authorized users can interact with the chatbot, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or impersonation. MFA can include a combination of something the user knows (password), something the user has (smartphone or hardware token), or something the user is (biometric authentication).

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Best Practices

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Set limits on API usage to prevent abuse and ensure fair usage
countermeasure.desc:
Implement rate limiting and usage quotas for API endpoints used by the chatbot to prevent abuse and ensure that resources are fairly distributed among all clients. By limiting the number of requests a user or system can make in a specific time period, you can mitigate the risk of denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, excessive load, or overconsumption of resources. Additionally, rate limiting helps maintain the chatbots availability and performance while protecting the backend services from being overwhelmed.

References:

  • OWASP API Security Top 10

standard.ref: ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Store data in secure locations with encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all sensitive data used by the chatbot, including user conversations and credentials, is stored in secure locations with encryption at rest. Encryption at rest ensures that data is protected when stored on disk or in databases, preventing unauthorized access in case of physical theft or unauthorized access attempts. Implement strong encryption methods and enforce strict access control policies to maintain data confidentiality and integrity.

References:

  • Encryption Standards

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: API abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
API abuse occurs when an attacker exploits exposed application programming interfaces (APIs) used by a chatbot to send malicious or excessive requests. This can result in unauthorized access, data theft, service degradation, or manipulation of chatbot responses. Without proper security controls, APIs can be misused for a variety of malicious activities such as flooding the system with requests or abusing API rate limits.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weak or poorly protected APIs to inject malicious inputs or perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.
  • Malicious Insiders: Abusing access to API endpoints or tokens to manipulate chatbot behaviors or extract sensitive data.
  • Automated Tools: Using botnets or scripts to flood the API with excessive requests, overloading the system.

Impacts

  • Data Theft or Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive user information passed through the chatbot's API.
  • Service Disruption: Overloading the chatbot's API with excessive requests, potentially resulting in downtime or degraded performance.
  • Unauthorized Actions: Manipulation of chatbot functionality, such as delivering malicious responses or altering user interactions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker discovers an unprotected API endpoint used by the chatbot and sends crafted input to steal user data.
  2. A malicious user scripts a DoS attack, sending massive amounts of API requests, making the chatbot unresponsive to legitimate users.
  3. An insider with API access exploits the chatbots API to modify conversation logs or redirect responses to malicious content.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Bias in chatbot responses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Bias in chatbot responses refers to the unintentional or systematic skewing of the chatbots replies based on biased training data or improper configuration. This can lead to discriminatory, unfair, or harmful responses that affect user experience, trust, and compliance with ethical standards. Bias in chatbot behavior can arise from biased datasets, poor design, or lack of diversity in training materials.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Manipulating input data or training materials to influence the chatbots responses in biased or harmful ways.
  • Internal Misconfigurations: Developers inadvertently training the chatbot on biased datasets, leading to skewed responses.
  • Data Poisoning: Attackers intentionally feeding the chatbot maliciously biased data to exploit or cause harm in specific use cases.

Impacts

  • User Trust Erosion: Users may lose confidence in the chatbots reliability and fairness, impacting brand reputation.
  • Legal and Ethical Violations: Biased responses could lead to legal challenges, particularly in sensitive areas like hiring, finance, or healthcare.
  • Discriminatory Behavior: Harmful biases could lead to discrimination or marginalization of certain user groups, negatively impacting inclusivity and user satisfaction.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A chatbot trained primarily on biased historical data provides discriminatory hiring recommendations based on gender or race.
  2. An attacker poisons the chatbots training dataset with harmful input to alter the chatbots responses towards a particular political ideology or controversial topic.
  3. A healthcare chatbot provides skewed medical advice based on biased training data, leading to incorrect or unsafe recommendations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

threat.name: User data leakage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
User data leakage occurs when sensitive user information, such as personal details, conversation logs, or payment information, is inadvertently exposed to unauthorized parties. This can happen due to improper data handling, insufficient access controls, insecure storage, or vulnerabilities in the chatbots infrastructure, leading to a breach of user privacy and trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities in the system, such as insecure API endpoints, to access or exfiltrate user data.
  • Malicious Insiders: Gaining unauthorized access to sensitive user data through excessive privileges or misconfigurations in access controls.
  • Insecure Data Storage: Storing sensitive information, such as user credentials or conversation logs, in unencrypted or publicly accessible locations.

Impacts

  • Privacy Violations: Exposed user data can lead to identity theft, fraud, or unauthorized sharing of personal information.
  • Reputation Damage: A data leakage incident can severely damage the chatbot's credibility and the trust users place in the platform.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Failure to protect user data could lead to violations of data protection regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or CCPA, resulting in fines and legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A chatbot stores user conversation logs in an unencrypted database, and an attacker exploits a vulnerability to retrieve these logs, exposing sensitive user information.
  2. A malicious insider with access to the chatbots admin panel uses excessive privileges to extract personal details from the system, such as names, addresses, or payment information.
  3. A chatbot's API fails to enforce proper access controls, allowing an attacker to access user data sent during interactions, such as email addresses or personal preferences.

threat.name: Integration risks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Integration risks refer to the potential vulnerabilities introduced when a chatbot interacts with external systems, APIs, or services. Improperly configured or insecure integrations can allow attackers to exploit weaknesses in the connection between systems, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches, or the execution of malicious actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weaknesses in external systems or APIs that the chatbot integrates with, allowing access to sensitive data or functionality.
  • Malicious Insiders: Manipulating chatbot integrations to divert data, access unauthorized resources, or inject malicious content.
  • Poorly Secured APIs: Using third-party APIs or services that do not implement proper authentication, encryption, or access control mechanisms, creating a potential attack surface.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Access: Attackers or malicious actors can gain access to sensitive data exchanged between the chatbot and external systems, leading to data breaches.
  • System Compromise: Exploiting insecure integrations to gain unauthorized control over connected systems or services, potentially damaging the integrity of the entire platform.
  • Service Disruption: A successful attack on an integrated third-party service could cause the chatbot to malfunction, leading to service outages or degraded user experience.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an insecure API endpoint used by the chatbot to access and manipulate sensitive user data stored in an external database.
  2. A malicious insider tampers with the chatbot's integration with a payment processing service, redirecting funds to their own account.
  3. A chatbot integrates with an external weather service, and the attacker exploits a vulnerability in the service's API to inject malicious code into the chatbots response.

threat.name: Data storage vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data storage vulnerabilities occur when sensitive information, such as user data, conversation logs, or other personal details, is stored insecurely within the chatbot's system. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper encryption, inadequate access controls, or poorly secured storage configurations, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access to or tamper with stored data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weaknesses in the storage system, such as unsecured databases or storage buckets, to steal or modify sensitive data.
  • Malicious Insiders: Gaining unauthorized access to stored data using excessive privileges or bypassing access controls.
  • Misconfigurations: Storing sensitive data in plain text or using weak encryption methods, making it easier for attackers to access or decrypt.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to stored sensitive data, such as personal information or confidential conversations, leading to identity theft, fraud, or privacy violations.
  • Data Integrity Loss: Attackers altering stored data, which could affect the chatbot's functionality or trustworthiness.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to properly secure data storage could lead to violations of regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS, resulting in fines and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured cloud storage bucket containing sensitive chatbot logs and conversation histories, gaining access to private user data.
  2. A malicious insider uses elevated privileges to access and modify the chatbot's data storage, tampering with user conversations or personal details.
  3. A vulnerability in the database used by the chatbot allows an attacker to execute SQL injection attacks and retrieve sensitive user data stored in plain text.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate user authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Inadequate user authentication occurs when the process used to verify a users identity is weak, improperly implemented, or easily bypassed. This can include relying on weak passwords, failing to implement multi-factor authentication (MFA), or using insecure authentication methods. Inadequate authentication increases the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive user data or application features.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Using techniques such as brute force attacks, credential stuffing, or exploiting weak password policies to gain unauthorized access to user accounts.
  • Malicious Insiders: Exploiting weak or poorly implemented authentication controls to escalate privileges or access sensitive data.
  • Automated Tools: Attackers leveraging botnets or automated scripts to exploit vulnerabilities in authentication systems, bypassing weak controls.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain unauthorized access to user accounts or services, leading to data breaches, financial loss, or abuse of services.
  • Data Theft: Sensitive personal data or business-critical information may be exposed to unauthorized users.
  • Reputation Damage: Weak authentication systems undermine user trust and can harm the organizations reputation, especially in the case of a breach.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a brute-force attack on a weak password policy to gain access to user accounts and steal sensitive data.
  2. A malicious user exploits a vulnerability in the authentication process, bypassing MFA controls and gaining unauthorized access to a users profile.
  3. A chatbot fails to verify user credentials securely and allows an attacker to impersonate a legitimate user by guessing simple passwords or using stolen credentials.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential bias in the data
countermeasure.desc:
Measuring and mitigating the effects of potential biases and discriminatory patterns in the data is an important step to make ML/AI models fairer, especially in socially sensitive decision processes.

1. Conduct an initial data exploration to understand the distribution and characteristics of your dataset. 
2. Utilize statistical techniques such as correlation analysis to identify any patterns that may indicate biases. 
3. Implement data pre-processing steps like balancing datasets or using techniques such as oversampling to address imbalances. 
4. Regularly review your data sources and update your model to ensure ongoing fairness and accountability. 
5. Document the steps taken to identify and mitigate bias for transparency and auditability.

reference.name: Bias Testing for Generalized Machine Learning Applications

countermeasure.name: Maintain data quality and integrity during data pre-processing
countermeasure.desc:
Maintaining data quality is an essential practice when developing ML/AI models. This allows for a reliable data pipeline, including the data cleaning and feature engineering steps. 

Developers might not always be aware of best practices for preparing or transforming the data for a given model type, which can lead to suboptimal representations of input features.

Some of the steps to avoid issues are:

Step 1: Standardize numerical features to prevent issues caused by differing scales.

Step 2: Handle missing data properly by assigning them meaningful values, such as using a designated placeholder.

Step 3: Validate and clean malformed values, especially in special string types like dates, to prevent model inaccuracies.

Remember to define a schema or constraints for data validation based on the initial data, expected evolution, and model requirements. Embrace automation tools to detect and address common data issues efficiently.

reference.name: The Data Linter: Lightweight, Automated Sanity Checking for ML Data Sets

countermeasure.name: Monitor for data drift, especially for new data and future online models
countermeasure.desc:
Data drift is a type of model drift where the properties of the independent variables change, e.g., input distribution changes. There are some basic monitoring measures to consider, including the use of statistical tests over time:

  • Regularly assess the cumulative distributions of your initial training data and post-training data. Use statistical tests like the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for comparison.
  • Track changes in variable distributions using metrics like the Population Stability Index.
  • Continuously monitor and compare feature distributions between the training data and post-training data, leveraging methods like Z-score analysis.
  • Calculate observed values against their mean and set a threshold for deviations. Employ tests like the Page-Hinkley test for this evaluation.

Utilize libraries and built-in verification tools within ML/AI frameworks, such as TensorFlow, to automate and streamline the monitoring process.

reference.name: Alibi Detect: A Python library focused on outlier, adversarial and drift detection
Frouros: A Python library for drift detection

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Changing data distribution and properties will affect the performance of the future model
threat.desc:
General Threat Description: This threat concerns the potential impact of evolving data properties and distribution on the performance of machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) systems. As data evolves over time, its distribution may change due to shifts in underlying patterns, behaviors, or external factors influencing the data generation process. These changes can affect how well an ML model, initially trained on a specific dataset, performs when exposed to new data. If not anticipated and managed appropriately, such changes can degrade model accuracy and utility, leading to poor decision-making.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors: While often a natural consequence of dynamic environments, deliberate manipulation of data distribution by adversaries can also induce this threat. Attack vectors include data poisoning, where malicious inputs are introduced to subtly shift the data distribution, and model evasion techniques, where attackers craft inputs specifically designed to exploit model weaknesses that emerge as data changes.

Impacts: The impacts include reduced model reliability, increased error rates, and potentially costly adjustments such as retraining or redesigning the model. In critical applications, such as medical diagnostics or financial forecasting, these impacts can translate into significant financial losses, endangerment of lives, and loss of credibility.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. A financial fraud detection model gradually becomes ineffective as fraud techniques evolve, leading to increased false negatives and significant financial losses due to undetected fraudulent transactions.
  2. Attackers manipulate the data input to a real-time traffic management system during a major public event, causing the system to mispredict traffic flows and leading to congestion or safety incidents.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565 - Data Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.TA0009 - Collection

threat.name: Data encoding, normalization, filtering, feature selection, and annotation, may all introduce biases or affect the predictive and generalization qualities of the model
threat.desc:
General Threat Description: This threat concerns the potential introduction of biases or the compromise of predictive accuracy during the data preparation stages of ML/AI model development. Key processes such as data encoding, normalization, filtering, feature selection, and annotation are critical in transforming raw data into a format suitable for learning algorithms. If improperly managed, these processes can inadvertently introduce biases or distortions that compromise the model's performance and security. For instance, poor feature engineering might oversimplify complex data, inadequate encoding could lead to information loss, and improper normalization may skew the data distribution, affecting the models ability to generalize from training to real-world application. Important aspects to take into consideration are:

  • Feature discovery/engineering, which relies on the type of data.
  • Encoding: both data and feature encoding should be carefully considered, e.g., to avoid information loss.
  • Normalization: essentially to use a common scale throughout the data.
  • Partitioning: care must be taken when creating data partitions. 
  • Other data manipulation or helpers: such as data filters or randomness, which plays an important role in stochastic systems.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors: Threat agents can range from data scientists who make unintentional errors to malicious insiders or external attackers who deliberately manipulate preprocessing steps. Attack vectors include the introduction of biased or skewed data at the input stage, manipulation of data handling rules, and exploitation of weaknesses in data preprocessing algorithms.

Impacts: The impacts of such biases and distortions include reduced model accuracy, unfair outcomes (especially in sensitive applications like hiring or law enforcement), and decreased user trust. In critical systems, these issues can lead to significant operational risks, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. A data scientist unintentionally uses an inappropriate method for data normalization in a credit scoring model, causing certain demographic groups to be unfairly penalized based on their spending behaviors which are misinterpreted by the model.
  2. An attacker manipulates the feature selection process in a healthcare diagnostic tool, causing it to ignore critical indicators of a specific disease, leading to widespread misdiagnoses and inadequate patient care.

reference.name: A Comprehensive Guide to Data Preprocessing

customField.value: ATLAS - AML.T0017 - Develop Capabilities||ATLAS - AML.TA0003 - Resource Development

weakness.name: CWE-308 CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required. CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319 CWE-354 CWE-311
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
CWE-354: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences. CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-453
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-453: Insecure Default Variable Initialization The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

weakness.name: CWE-77
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-77: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection') The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enforce input validation and sanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Identify All Inputs:

  • Catalog all points where data is received, including user forms, API endpoints, query parameters, and file uploads.

Define Input Rules:

  • Determine acceptable data types, formats, and ranges for each input. For example:
    • Numbers should fall within specified ranges.
    • Strings must conform to allowed character sets or patterns (e.g., email addresses).
    • Files should only have specific, allowed MIME types.

Implement Server-Side Validation:

  • Check Types and Formats: Use strict checks for data types, lengths, and formats using regular expressions or parsing functions.
  • Range Checking: Ensure numeric inputs fall within valid ranges and string lengths are bounded.
  • Required Fields: Confirm required fields are provided and contain valid data.

Sanitize Inputs:

  • Escape Special Characters: Escape or encode characters to neutralize code injection risks. For example, escape HTML entities or use parameterized SQL queries.
  • Strip Invalid Characters: Remove unwanted characters, whitespace, or control characters that don't meet the expected input format.

Reject Invalid Inputs:

  • Return clear error messages with an appropriate HTTP status code (e.g., 400 Bad Request) while ensuring sensitive details are not exposed.

Client-Side Validation (Supplementary):

  • Implement client-side validation for a better user experience but never rely on it exclusively for security purposes.

Input Logging and Monitoring:

  • Log suspicious inputs or repeated validation failures for further analysis.
  • Monitor these logs to identify potential attack attempts or input pattern changes.

Regular Security Reviews:

  • Review and update validation rules based on changing business logic or new threat models.
  • Conduct code reviews and penetration testing focused on injection vulnerabilities.

These actions will ensure input validation and sanitization protect against common injection vulnerabilities, enhancing the overall security posture.

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - M0818 - Validate Program Inputs

countermeasure.name: Ensure comprehensive data protection measures
countermeasure.desc:
In today's digital landscape, protecting sensitive data against tampering and unauthorized access is paramount for maintaining its integrity and confidentiality. Implementing Comprehensive Data Protection Measures is critical to achieving this goal. These measures encompass a variety of techniques designed to secure data at every stage of its lifecycle. Here's how developers can effectively implement these data protection strategies:

  1. Ensuring Data Integrity with Cryptographic Hashes: Utilize cryptographic hashing algorithms (e.g., SHA-256) to generate a unique hash value for your data. This hash acts as a digital fingerprint, allowing any alteration of the data to be easily detected. Hashing is vital for verifying data integrity during transmission or storage.
  2. Utilizing Digital Signatures: Digital signatures provide a means to verify the authenticity and integrity of data. By signing data with a private key and allowing verification with the corresponding public key, you can ensure that data has not been tampered with and confirm its origin.
  3. Applying Strong Encryption:
    • Data at Rest: Encrypt sensitive data stored on persistent media using robust encryption standards like AES-256. This protects the data against unauthorized access if the storage medium is compromised.
    • Data in Transit: Use protocols like TLS/SSL to encrypt data during transmission over networks. This prevents data from being intercepted and read by unauthorized parties.
  4. Key Management: Implement secure key management practices to protect encryption keys. This includes storing keys in a dedicated hardware security module (HSM), using key rotation policies, and ensuring that keys are accessible only to authorized applications and users.
  5. Regular Security Audits: Conduct periodic security audits and vulnerability assessments to identify and address potential weaknesses in your data protection measures. This includes reviewing encryption protocols, access controls, and compliance with relevant security standards.

By adopting these comprehensive data protection measures, developers can significantly enhance the security of sensitive data within the Data Processing Component. These practices not only help in protecting data from external threats but also bolster trust in the system's ability to safeguard valuable information.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive security configuration and vulnerability management
countermeasure.desc:
Inventory Assets: Compile an up-to-date list of all hardware, software, operating systems, and network devices used in the system. Include versions and configurations for each asset.

Baseline Configurations:

  • Establish secure baseline configurations for each asset type based on industry best practices (e.g., CIS Benchmarks).
  • Disable or remove unnecessary services, ports, and software to minimize attack surface.

Configuration Management:

  • Policies: Create a strict policy outlining approved changes to configurations.
  • Version Control: Use a version control system to track configuration changes.
  • Monitoring: Continuously monitor configurations for unauthorized changes and alert administrators.

Patch Management:

  • Automated Updates: Enable automated updates where feasible, particularly for high-risk software and services.
  • Manual Patching: Create a regular patching schedule for critical vulnerabilities that require manual intervention.
  • Testing: Test patches in a staging environment before deploying to production.

Vulnerability Scanning:

  • Use automated tools to regularly scan the entire system for known vulnerabilities.
  • Prioritize vulnerabilities based on criticality and exposure level, and assign remediation timelines accordingly.

Penetration Testing:

  • Conduct regular penetration testing to uncover vulnerabilities not covered by automated scans.
  • Engage third-party testers to validate internal security assumptions.

Incident Response Plan:

  • Develop and document procedures for responding to security incidents stemming from misconfigurations or unpatched vulnerabilities.
  • Train teams on identifying and reacting to incidents efficiently.

Auditing and Reporting:

  • Maintain detailed logs of configuration changes, vulnerability scans, and patch deployments.
  • Audit regularly to ensure compliance with internal policies and external regulations.

Continuous Improvement:

  • Periodically review configuration baselines and update them to accommodate new threats or industry guidelines.
  • Incorporate findings from incident reports into improved security practices.

These steps will ensure that configurations remain secure and vulnerabilities are swiftly managed, reducing exposure to emerging threats.

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and traffic analysis
countermeasure.desc:
Identify Traffic Sources:

  • Analyze and categorize typical traffic sources, like client IP addresses or API keys, and determine which should be subject to rate limiting. Examples include web clients, internal services, and third-party applications.

Establish Rate Limiting Policies:

  • Define Limits: Set rate limits based on endpoint criticality and business requirements. Common metrics include requests per second, per minute, or per hour.
  • Granularity: Apply limits to specific IP addresses, API keys, user accounts, or other identifiers as appropriate.

Choose Implementation Strategy:

  • Server-Side Limiting: Implement rate limiting at the application level through middleware, frameworks, or server modules like NGINX.
  • Third-Party Solutions: Use cloud or third-party services like AWS API Gateway or Cloudflare to manage traffic limits externally.

Integrate Traffic Analysis:

  • Logging: Log traffic metadata, including source IPs, URLs, and request timestamps.
  • Monitoring Tools: Use monitoring tools to visualize traffic patterns, detect anomalies, and trigger alerts on suspicious spikes.
  • Traffic Baseline: Establish baselines for "normal" traffic patterns to help identify deviations.

Throttling and Blocking:

  • Throttling: Gracefully throttle traffic exceeding the defined limit, returning HTTP status code 429 (Too Many Requests) or similar.
  • Blocking: Temporarily or permanently block clients that continually violate rate limits.

Alerting and Incident Management:

  • Configure alerts to notify the security team when rate limits are breached.
  • Document procedures to handle and investigate incidents involving abuse or potential attacks.

Feedback Loop:

  • Review logs, alerts, and traffic analysis reports to refine rate limiting thresholds over time.
  • Use traffic data to enhance the understanding of user behavior and detect emerging attack patterns.

These steps will help you minimize the risk of service abuse while ensuring legitimate traffic remains uninterrupted.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure software supply chain management
countermeasure.desc:
Inventory and Catalog:

  • Identify all software components, dependencies, and third-party libraries in your supply chain, including open-source and proprietary software.
  • Maintain an up-to-date inventory of software versions and configurations.

Select Trusted Sources:

  • Download libraries, tools, and dependencies only from trusted, verified sources (e.g., official vendor sites or verified package managers like npm, Maven, or PyPI).
  • Verify checksums or digital signatures when available.

Assess Security Risks:

  • Perform security assessments of third-party vendors and libraries to identify known vulnerabilities or questionable practices.
  • Implement policies for onboarding new vendors, emphasizing adherence to secure coding standards.

Integrate Scanning and Testing:

  • Static Analysis: Use static code analysis tools to scan source code for vulnerabilities.
  • Dependency Scanning: Automate scanning for known vulnerabilities in dependencies using tools like OWASP Dependency-Check or Snyk.
  • Dynamic Testing: Conduct dynamic application security testing (DAST) to uncover runtime vulnerabilities.

Patch Management:

  • Stay updated on security advisories and vulnerability databases (e.g., CVE database, NVD).
  • Promptly apply patches or updates to third-party libraries, frameworks, and tools.

Control the Build Environment:

  • Isolate the build environment to reduce exposure to unauthorized access.
  • Ensure integrity by using reproducible builds with tools like Docker or Buildpacks.
  • Sign your builds and verify signatures at each stage to detect tampering.

Implement Access Controls:

  • Enforce least-privilege access to build servers, version control systems, and package repositories.
  • Regularly review permissions for contractors or external contributors.

Monitor and Respond:

  • Monitor for suspicious activity in the build environment, such as unauthorized access or unexpected changes.
  • Develop an incident response plan tailored to supply chain attacks, emphasizing quick containment and recovery.

Supply Chain Policies:

  • Establish and enforce policies around third-party software usage, including requirements for licensing, version control, and regular security reviews.
  • Educate development teams on supply chain risks and secure coding practices.

These steps will help ensure the integrity of your software supply chain and minimize the risk of malicious or compromised components.

countermeasure.name: Strengthen authentication and access control
countermeasure.desc:
Authentication Methods:

  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enable MFA for all users to add an extra layer of security beyond just passwords. Common factors include TOTP (Google Authenticator) or hardware tokens (YubiKey).
  • Single Sign-On (SSO): Integrate with an SSO provider to centralize authentication and reduce reliance on multiple passwords.
  • Password Policies: Enforce strong password policies such as minimum length, complexity requirements, and periodic password rotation.

Access Controls:

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Assign permissions based on user roles to minimize the exposure of sensitive functions and data.
  • Least Privilege: Ensure that users have only the minimum necessary permissions to perform their tasks. Review and revoke excessive privileges regularly.

Authentication Protocols:

  • Use secure authentication protocols like OAuth2, SAML, or OpenID Connect for web services.
  • Ensure all data transfers during authentication are encrypted (e.g., via TLS/SSL).

Session Management:

  • Implement secure session management to prevent session hijacking and fixation:
    • Use secure cookies (HTTPOnly and Secure flags) to store session tokens.
    • Regenerate session tokens upon authentication and privilege escalation.
    • Set session expiration times and inactivity logout.

Account Lockout and Recovery:

  • Implement automatic account lockout after repeated failed login attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Provide secure account recovery options, such as email or SMS verification, ensuring that recovery information is validated and updated.

Logging and Monitoring:

  • Log authentication attempts, password changes, and privilege escalations for auditing purposes.
  • Monitor access patterns and trigger alerts for suspicious activities, such as repeated login failures or sudden privilege changes.

Regular Audits and Reviews:

  • Conduct regular audits of user accounts and roles to ensure compliance with access control policies.
  • Review logs and monitoring alerts to identify and investigate unusual behavior.

Security Education:

  • Train users on secure authentication practices, like recognizing phishing attacks and maintaining strong, unique passwords.

Implementing these measures will significantly reduce unauthorized access risks and strengthen overall authentication security.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers perform a Denial of Service (DoS)
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A Denial of Service (DoS) attack is a malicious attempt to disrupt the normal operations of a targeted system, network, or application, typically by overwhelming it with a flood of Internet traffic. DoS attacks exploit limitations in the resources handling capabilities of systems, such as bandwidth, disk space, or processor time, rendering the service slow or completely unresponsive to legitimate users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

DoS attacks can be launched from a single machine (simple DoS) or multiple systems (Distributed Denial of Service, DDoS), involving compromised computers called bots, which form a botnet. Attack vectors include high volumes of network packets, requests that consume a lot of server resources, or requests that trigger non-optimized code paths in software. Common methods involve TCP SYN floods, UDP floods, ICMP floods, and other protocol-specific attacks.

Impacts

The primary impact of a DoS attack is the unavailability of services, which can lead to significant disruptions in user access, loss of business transactions, erosion of trust by users, and financial losses. For data processing systems specifically, a DoS can delay or stop the processing of critical data, affecting decision-making or operational efficiency. Recovery and mitigation can also lead to additional overhead in terms of system hardening and countermeasure implementation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker targets a financial services data processing API with a SYN flood, exploiting the TCP handshake mechanism. By not completing the handshakes, the attacker depletes server resources, preventing legitimate user requests from being processed.

Scenario 2: A competitor orchestrates a UDP flood attack against a real-time data analytics service during a major business event. The flood overwhelms the network, causing legitimate traffic to be dropped and the analytics service to become unavailable during a critical time.

Scenario 3: An attacker discovers that a particular API endpoint on a data processing system performs complex queries without proper optimization. They send multiple high-complexity requests to this endpoint, each of which consumes significant server resources, slowing down the system dramatically and eventually leading to service outage.

Each of these scenarios illustrates how attackers can exploit different aspects of the network and application to initiate a DoS attack, disrupting services and causing significant business impact.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exploit poorly protected data for alteration or disclosure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
This threat involves attackers exploiting weak data security to alter, steal, or disclose sensitive data. Poor data protection may occur due to misconfigured security settings, inadequate encryption, or a lack of access controls, allowing malicious actors to tamper with or gain unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external hackers, nation-state actors, and organized crime groups.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting software vulnerabilities, intercepting unencrypted data during transmission, exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, phishing for access credentials, or using malware to manipulate files.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity: Unauthorized changes can corrupt data, leading to incorrect or misleading information.
  • Data Confidentiality: Sensitive data exposure can result in personal, financial, or proprietary information being disclosed.
  • Operational Disruption: Data alterations can cause workflow interruptions, leading to delays, inefficiencies, or system downtimes.
  • Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data privacy regulations may lead to fines or legal action.
  • Reputational Damage: A breach in data security can erode customer trust, harming the organizations reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted data traffic between a client and a server, extracting sensitive customer data like credit card information and personal details.

Scenario 2: A phishing attack targets a system administrator, resulting in compromised credentials that allow the attacker to alter crucial financial records in the database.

Scenario 3: A developer uses an outdated, insecure data processing library, which contains a vulnerability. An attacker exploits this to manipulate and extract confidential business data, disrupting internal workflows.

Ensuring data is encrypted, regularly audited, and protected by strict access controls is vital in mitigating these risks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1485 - Data Destruction||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.001 - Stored Data Manipulation||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.002 - Transmitted Data Manipulation

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers bypass access controls to gain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control bypass occurs when attackers exploit vulnerabilities or weaknesses in an application's security measures to gain unauthorized access to restricted resources. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive data by circumventing authentication or authorization mechanisms, either by manipulating session data, exploiting bugs, or leveraging overly permissive permissions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Hackers: Exploit flaws in web applications, network protocols, or poorly configured access control rules to gain entry.
  • Malicious Insiders: Abuse existing permissions or find ways around access controls by exploiting knowledge of the internal infrastructure.
  • Automated Bots/Scanners: Search for and attack common vulnerabilities in access control mechanisms or weak configurations.

Common attack vectors include:

  • Broken Authentication/Authorization: Manipulating session tokens or exploiting logic errors to escalate privileges.
  • Unvalidated Input: Using injection attacks (e.g., SQL injection, LDAP injection) to gain unauthorized access.
  • Overly Broad Permissions: Misconfigured access control policies that provide excessive permissions.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Attackers can access sensitive or confidential data, resulting in data loss or exposure.
  • Privilege Escalation: An attacker gains higher-level privileges than intended, compromising critical systems.
  • System Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modifications to system configurations, logs, or business logic.
  • Reputational and Financial Damage: Breached systems can lead to legal penalties, loss of revenue, and customer trust erosion.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that the application's password reset function is vulnerable to brute force attacks. They exploit this by rapidly attempting username and email combinations to gain access to multiple accounts.

Scenario 2: A web application uses predictable session tokens, which an attacker identifies through analysis. By manipulating the token, they gain unauthorized access to other users' sessions.

Scenario 3: An internal API endpoint designed for admin users lacks proper authentication checks. An attacker discovers this through API documentation and uses the endpoint to access sensitive configuration data without valid credentials.

These scenarios demonstrate how attackers can exploit flaws in access control systems, leading to severe security breaches that expose sensitive information and compromise the affected systems.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1136.001 - Local Account||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1136.002 - Domain Account||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548.003 - Sudo and Sudo Caching

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers obtain unauthorized access exploiting supply chain attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In a supply chain attack, attackers compromise a trusted third-party service or component to gain unauthorized access to a target organization. This type of attack exploits the interconnectedness of modern software ecosystems, where applications often rely on external code, libraries, hardware, or services. Once a trusted vendor is compromised, attackers insert malicious code, tamper with software, or alter device firmware to gain access to the target organization, spread malware, or collect sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) Groups: Often state-sponsored or highly organized groups that target critical infrastructure or large corporations for espionage.
  • Cybercriminals: Target widely used software or services to profit from ransomware attacks or data theft.
  • Insiders: Malicious insiders in supplier organizations intentionally insert backdoors or other vulnerabilities.

Common attack vectors include:

  • Compromised Development Tools: Modifying compilers, code repositories, or build servers to inject malicious code into trusted software products.
  • Software Libraries and Dependencies: Inserting malicious code into open-source libraries or third-party software components that are widely used.
  • Hardware/Firmware Tampering: Manipulating hardware components during manufacturing or distribution to install backdoors or keyloggers.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Attackers can gain access to sensitive information through compromised software, leading to data theft or leakage.
  • Malware Spread: Infected software updates or applications can propagate malware across entire networks.
  • Service Disruption: Compromised systems may be used to execute ransomware attacks or DDoS campaigns, leading to service downtime and operational impact.
  • Financial and Reputational Damage: Organizations may face legal penalties, lost revenue, or a decline in user trust due to compromised customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker gains access to the build environment of a popular software vendor. They alter the source code of a widely used library to include a backdoor, which is distributed to all users through the vendor's next software update.

Scenario 2: An open-source NPM package used in thousands of web applications is tampered with by a malicious contributor. The compromised package sends environment variables, including API keys and credentials, to a command-and-control server.

Scenario 3: An attacker manipulates the firmware in network switches during manufacturing, adding a hidden feature that allows unauthorized access. Once the switches are deployed in a corporate environment, the attacker gains control and exfiltrates network traffic.

These scenarios illustrate how attackers can exploit the trust placed in suppliers and third-party components, compromising software development and distribution to gain unauthorized access to otherwise secure environments.

reference.name: NIST Supply Chain Risk Management Practices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise||ATT&CK ICS - T0862 - Supply Chain Compromise||ATT&CK Mobile - T1474 - Supply Chain Compromise

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations and vulnerable Third-Party Dependencies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exploiting misconfigurations and vulnerable third-party dependencies involves attackers taking advantage of insecure software configurations and known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or frameworks used within an application. Misconfigurations, such as insecure permissions or exposed management interfaces, can provide unauthorized access. Meanwhile, unpatched third-party components can contain vulnerabilities that are easily exploited, often allowing attackers to execute malicious code, steal sensitive data, or gain deeper access into a network.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents typically include:

  • External Hackers: Exploit vulnerabilities in web servers, network devices, or software dependencies to gain unauthorized access or execute arbitrary code.
  • Malicious Insiders: Utilize knowledge of internal systems to identify misconfigurations that provide higher privileges or data access.
  • Automated Bots/Scanners: Bots scan the Internet to detect exposed systems with insecure configurations or outdated dependencies.

Common attack vectors include:

  • Unpatched Libraries: Attacking applications that use libraries or frameworks with known vulnerabilities.
  • Open Ports: Accessing unsecured ports and exploiting exposed management interfaces or services.
  • Improper Permissions: Leveraging files or directories with excessive permissions to read or modify critical data.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Attackers may gain unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to data theft or leakage.
  • System Compromise: Unpatched or misconfigured systems may be fully compromised, enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code or move laterally through the network.
  • Service Disruption: An attacker might disrupt services by disabling critical components or making unauthorized changes to the application.
  • Reputational Damage: Exposure of sensitive customer information or prolonged service downtime can damage user trust and company reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An application uses an outdated version of an open-source image processing library that contains a known buffer overflow vulnerability. An attacker crafts a malicious image that triggers the buffer overflow, giving them remote code execution access and leading to a data breach.

Scenario 2: A developer unintentionally exposes an administrative management console of a cloud service due to a misconfigured firewall rule. An attacker finds this interface, gains administrator access, and deletes critical application data.

Scenario 3: An internal system contains debugging information that is accidentally left exposed with read permissions to all users. An attacker discovers this misconfiguration, accesses the debug logs, and uses sensitive information to escalate privileges.

These scenarios highlight how attackers can exploit weaknesses in software configurations and third-party dependencies, leading to potentially severe security breaches and service interruptions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Attackers obtain unauthorized access through injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Injection attacks occur when an attacker sends malicious data to an application, tricking it into executing unintended commands. By exploiting inadequate input validation, attackers can inject malicious code into queries or commands processed by an interpreter. Common types include SQL injection (SQLi), cross-site scripting (XSS), and command injection. Injection attacks can lead to data breaches, unauthorized system access, or the complete takeover of an application.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Hackers: Exploit vulnerabilities in web applications, APIs, or other systems by crafting malicious input strings that are passed to an interpreter.
  • Malicious Insiders: Leverage knowledge of internal application functions to inject commands with greater precision.
  • Automated Bots/Scanners: Scan web applications to identify forms and parameters that could be exploited for injection attacks.

Common attack vectors include:

  • SQL Injection: Embedding SQL commands within input fields or URLs to manipulate database queries.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Injecting malicious JavaScript into web pages viewed by other users.
  • Command Injection: Sending shell commands through input fields or URLs to execute arbitrary system commands.

Impacts

  • Data Theft/Manipulation: Attackers can read, modify, or delete sensitive data stored in databases.
  • Service Disruption: Injection attacks can modify or delete crucial data, disrupt services, or render applications unusable.
  • Unauthorized Access: Gaining administrative control over systems or servers by escalating privileges.
  • System Compromise: Execution of arbitrary commands can compromise servers, leading to malware installation or network penetration.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker targets a web application with a vulnerable search form, injecting an SQL statement like '; DROP TABLE users; -- to delete the entire user database.

Scenario 2: A developer overlooks input validation for user comments in a forum. An attacker posts a comment with malicious JavaScript that steals cookies from any user viewing the comment.

Scenario 3: An application accepts user input to execute system commands for file operations. The attacker injects ; rm -rf /; into the file name input, tricking the server into deleting critical files.

These scenarios highlight the significant risks posed by injection attacks, which can cause severe data breaches or service disruptions if input data is not properly sanitized before being passed to interpreters.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-489
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-489: Active Debug Code The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information. A common development practice is to add "back door" code specifically designed for debugging or testing purposes that is not intended to be shipped or deployed with the product. These back door entry points create security risks because they are not considered during design or testing and fall outside of the expected operating conditions of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-799
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-799: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency The product does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor, such as the number of incoming requests. This can allow the actor to perform actions more frequently than expected. The actor could be a human or an automated process such as a virus or bot. This could be used to cause a denial of service, compromise program logic (such as limiting humans to a single vote), or other consequences. For example, an authentication routine might not limit the number of times an attacker can guess a password. Or, a web site might conduct a poll but only expect humans to vote a maximum of once a day.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Consider possible defenses at the deployment stage to secure the outputs and/or the model
countermeasure.desc:
There is an increasing demand for privacy-preserving techniques in ML/AI, at all levels, from training to inference. While there is no silver bullet when it comes to achieving privacy in ML/AI, certain mechanisms can be used to further secure the outputs and/or the model, including:

  1. Implement obfuscation techniques, particularly for models deployed on devices, to obscure their inner workings.
  2. Utilize encryption methods like homomorphic encryption to allow for secure training, inference, and output generation with encrypted data.
  3. Opt for decentralized data handling through federated machine learning to enhance both input and output privacy protections.
  4. Introduce noise to the data or employ regularization techniques to enhance anonymity while maintaining model accuracy.

Several ML/AI tools now provide built-in privacy-preserving features, such as Tensorflow and PyTorch. Consider utilizing tools like Seldon Core or Evidently, which offer security and monitoring capabilities for model deployment.

Additionally, enhance output and model privacy with data engineering solutions. Implement robust authentication, authorization, and proxy/token-based access controls for inference processes.

countermeasure.name: Control the access to data, models, and components in production
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure proper access control by: 

Restricting access on the back-end: 

  • Implement strong access controls on the server side to regulate who can interact with the model, its code, data, and associated components like designs and validation plans. 
  • Utilize authentication mechanisms to verify the identity of users trying to access sensitive components. 

Authenticating users on the client side: 

  • Ensure that users are authenticated before granting them access to the AI system for utilizing the model. 
  • Employ secure authentication methods, such as multi-factor authentication, to enhance user verification. 

By controlling access to data, models, and components both on the server and client sides, you can bolster the security of the AI system and prevent unauthorized access or misuse of sensitive resources. Remember to follow best practices for access control and authentication to safeguard the system from potential threats.

countermeasure.name: Implement a mandatory security review to sanitize deployment configurations from preprints
countermeasure.desc:
Deployment configurations and code examples from external sources are often designed for ease of use, not for production security. They frequently contain insecure defaults, such as running as a root user, using latest tags, or having overly permissive network settings. To mitigate this risk, you must have a formal process to "sanitize" this code by rewriting it to conform to your organization's own secure standards.

A DevOps or platform security engineer should implement this by establishing the following workflow:

  1. Prohibit the Direct Use of External Configurations
    • You must have a formal policy that prohibits developers from directly deploying any configuration file, Dockerfile, or deployment manifest that was copied from an unvetted, external source (e.g., a public Git repository, a blog post, or a research paper).
  2. Maintain a Library of Hardened Base Templates
    • You must create and maintain a central, version-controlled repository of "golden" Infrastructure as Code (IaC) templates for all common deployment artifacts (e.g., Dockerfile, Kubernetes Deployment, NetworkPolicy).
    • These templates must be pre-configured with your organization's security baseline, in accordance with industry standards like the CIS Benchmarks.
  3. Implement a Mandatory Sanitization and Rewrite Process
    • When a developer wants to deploy a new third-party application or model, they must submit the external example configuration for a security review.
    • The security or platform engineering team is then responsible for using this external configuration as a reference only. They must rewrite the deployment logic from the ground up using your approved, internal, hardened templates.
  4. Enforce with a Policy-as-Code Gate
    • Your CI/CD pipeline for infrastructure deployment must use a Policy-as-Code scanner (e.g., Checkov, Kyverno).
    • This tool must be configured to validate that all deployed resources comply with your hardening standards, effectively blocking any un-sanitized, copy-pasted configurations from reaching production.

References:

  • NIST Secure Software Development Framework (SSDF) - PW.1: Secure Settings by Default
  • CIS Benchmarks (Center for Internet Security)

countermeasure.name: Inject all configurations during the deployment setup from a secure secrets management service
countermeasure.desc:
Hardcoding secrets, API keys, or any environment-specific configuration into your application's source code or build artifacts is a critical security vulnerability and an operational anti-pattern. You must externalize all such configuration into a dedicated, secure, and auditable secrets management service.

A developer or DevOps engineer should implement this by establishing the following secure pattern:

  1. Use a Central Secrets Management Service
    • You must store all application secrets (passwords, API keys, certificates) and environment-specific configuration variables in a dedicated, hardened secrets vault, such as HashiCorp Vault or a cloud-native equivalent.
  2. Prohibit Hardcoded Configuration
    • You must enforce a policy, verified by automated secret scanning in your CI/CD pipeline, that prohibits the presence of any secrets in source code, configuration files, build artifacts, or container images.
  3. Implement a Runtime Injection Pattern
    • Your application must be architected to receive its configuration when it starts, not when it's built. The two recommended patterns for this are:
    • Application-led Injection: The application, upon startup, uses a secure workload identity to authenticate directly to the secrets vault and pull its required configuration.
    • Platform-led Injection: The deployment orchestrator (e.g., Kubernetes) uses a native integration like the Secrets Store CSI Driver. This driver fetches the secrets from the vault and securely mounts them into the application's container as files or environment variables just before the application process starts.

References:

  • The Twelve-Factor App - III. Config
  • OWASP Application Security Verification Standard (ASVS) - V6: Stored Cryptography

countermeasure.name: Models in production should be able to recover to a known state, reset, or be 'cleaned' if necessary
countermeasure.desc:
Implement failover mechanisms and establish a robust business continuity plan by following these steps:

  • Locally manage your code base and regularly back it up to a remote repository to prevent code loss in case of failures.
  • Backup all data, including generated versioned models, essential notebooks, and configuration files, to maintain data integrity and availability.
  • Automate deployments using scripts to streamline the process and reduce human errors.
  • Utilize geo-replication for data storage/accounts to ensure redundancy and fault tolerance, especially if deploying on a Cloud platform.

countermeasure.name: Monitor for errors and model drift by continuously tracking the model's performance metrics in production
countermeasure.desc:
Model drift detection is an active research field. New methods are continuously being proposed in the literature. There are, however, some basic monitoring measures to consider, including:

  1. Continuously track the model's accuracy using metrics like F-score.
  2. Utilize statistical tests such as Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to compare data distributions before and after training.
  3. Calculate the Population Stability Index to measure changes in variable distributions over time.
  4. Use Z-score to compare feature distributions between training and live data.
  5. Set up a regular retraining schedule for the model to address any detected drift.
  6. Implement a human-in-the-loop process to periodically assess the model's performance.

By following these steps, you can effectively monitor for model drift and take proactive measures to maintain the performance and reliability of the AI system. Remember that continuous monitoring and timely actions are key practices in ensuring the security and effectiveness of machine learning models in production environments.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the number of model queries
countermeasure.desc:
Protect your system by defining a resource access policy to limit the size and frequency of user queries. Follow these steps to implement proper rate limiting:

  • Set specific limits to control traffic from individual sources, ensuring users stay within their allocated query limits.
  • Implement global limits to manage overall traffic entering the system from all sources, ensuring the total rate limit does not exceed the system's tested capacity or what is reasonable for the model's task.

By combining both individual and global rate limits, you can defend your system against potential denial of service attacks and ensure its stability.
